For those unfamiliar with the word, although it can, as clued, mean excited, TURNT is most often used in the context of intoxication or partying.  A person saying they're "Gonna get turnt" is not announcing their intent to get excited, and you also shouldn't tell your kids you "Got turnt" at dinner to mean that you drank a lot.  It's that combination of being under the influence and excited that usually gets you to turnt level.

An event or group of people described as turnt, however, are closer to what the clue indicated.  A wild party or rowdy crowd of fans after a game might be described as turnt regardless of their collective sobriety.

Your mileage may vary regionally, of course--just err on the side of caution.

The linked piece is just gibberish. @Caitlin, don‚Äôt believe everything you read on the internet!

It‚Äôs true that in casual speech ‚Äúaverage‚Äù may be used more loosely to mean ‚Äútypical.‚Äù If I say someone is of ‚Äúaverage‚Äù height I am not literally asserting that their height is the arithmetic mean of some well-defined population. But that‚Äôs just usage ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt change the fact that in math statistics (which are the sole domains in which ‚Äúmean‚Äù is used as a noun) the two words have identical meaning.

@Nat K
The missing word in this discussion is "median". You get a mean or average (yes, they are identical), by adding up all the widgets belonging to your widget collectors association and then dividing that total by the number of members. Et voil√†! Average number of widgets per member.
This is a meaningful piece of information for a fairly homogeneous group. But what happens when old Snidely Whiplash corners the market on widgets, buying up hundreds while leaving the rest of your members with one or two widgets each?
Your average remains unchanged -- same numbers for total widgets collected and number of collectors. But it no longer reflects the reality of widget distribution.
Here is where MEDIAN comes into its own. Imagine your members in a line arrayed by number of widgets collected. The median is the person at the exact middle of the line. We know it's not Snidely. He's over there on the far right chuckling at his heap of widgets. The median is going to be some poor sap who has a widget or two -- just like most of the association's members. A truer representative of the group's composition.
BONUS QUESTION: Should we use medians or averages to understand our economy?

@Puzzled Brit

The problem for all of you Brits is that you‚Äôre reading the clue wrong. Since this is an American paper, the clue means ‚ÄúWord equivalent to what we call ‚Äúbaths‚Äù here, in Bath (i.e. the UK).‚Äù  And here, a ‚Äúbath‚Äù can be the process of bathing in a tub, or the room it takes place in, or even a smaller room that doesn‚Äôt have the actual tub (here it is a euphemism). (Bath never means bathtub here.)

In ads for houses and apartments here, a property is described as having a number of full baths and half baths. The smaller ones are also called lavatories here, though infrequently.

Since all that is required is partial overlap, the clue works from an American standpoint. 

And we don‚Äôt really care if LAVS is too posh, too quaint or too archaic for the good husbands and wives of Bath. All that matters is that it‚Äôs British. 

The problem is that you‚Äôre only seeing it from a British standpoint.
